Teams net points while player is on the court.

article.description: The Heat were held to the fourth-lowest point total in NBA history, losing 95-56 to the Utah Jazz for their 18th defeat in 23 games.
article.headline: Heat's 56 points fourth-lowest in NBA history

images.name: Malone_Karl 121801 inline
images.caption: Karl Malone had 21 points and eight rebounds as the Jazz embarrassed Miami.

article.linkText: Heat held to 56 in 39-point home loss to Jazz
article.story:
MIAMI (AP) -- A surprisingly bad season took an embarrassing turn for the worse Tuesday night for the Miami Heat.
Fewest points scored
The fewest points scored by one team in an NBA game since the 24-second shot clock was introduced for the 1954-55 season (x-playoff game):
49: Bulls vs. Heat, April 10, 1999
54: x-Jazz at Bulls, June 7, 1998
55: Pacers vs. Spurs, March 29, 1998
56: Heat vs. Jazz, Dec. 18, 2001
56: Heat at Hornets, Dec. 20, 2000
56: Jazz at Sonics, Feb. 16, 1999
57: Magic vs. Cavs, Dec. 4, 1996
57: Sixers vs. Heat, Feb. 21, 1996
57: Bucks vs. Celtics at Providence, Feb. 27, 1955
58: Knicks vs. Jazz, Dec. 15, 2000
59: Blazers at Pacers, Feb. 27, 1998
59: Cavs at Spurs, March 25, 1997
59: Kings at Hornets, Jan. 10, 1991
61: Pacers at Cavs, March 22, 1994
61: Knicks at Pistons, April 12, 1992
61: Nuggets at Spurs, March 13, 1999
The Heat were held to the fourth-lowest point total in NBA history, losing 95-56 to the Utah Jazz for their 18th defeat in 23 games. Miami tied the franchise record for fewest points in a game, and their fans let them know about with a chorus of boos throughout. Miami also scored 56 points against Charlotte on Dec. 20, 2000. "I spent the whole game speechless," Heat forward Brian Grant said. "It was a lack of execution both offensively and defensively. They're a veteran team and they just outworked us. "It's over, but we're professionals and we're all better than that effort tonight. They just kept rolling and rolling and we didn't stop them." It was the Heat's lowest-scoring home game in franchise history, the previous low of 65 coming against Boston in their inaugural 1988-89 season. The Heat scored only 23 first-half points -- four more than the NBA record -- and made only 22.2 percent of their shots. "Without a doubt, this was a lack of mental and physical effort," Miami coach Pat Riley said. "Tonight we couldn't buy a shot, make a shot, make a rebound or make a pass. It was one thing after another. Once we got down 32-12, it was all over." Karl Malone and Donyell Marshall scored 21 points each for Utah, which set a team record for fewest points allowed. The Jazz previously allowed 58 in a 31-point win against the Knicks on Dec. 15, 2000. "The Heat just had a real tough time shooting the ball," Jazz coach Jerry Sloan said. "They had some decent looks at the basket, but the ball just didn't go down. I don't really think it was our defense by any stretch of the imagination. I just think the Heat are going through one of those times when they're not shooting the ball well, and that makes it tough." Malone, who sat out the fourth quarter, added eight rebounds and five assists as Utah won for the third time in its last four games. Marshall shot 7-of-10 from the floor and led the Jazz with 13 rebounds. "After two good days of practice, we had good concentration and that carried over into the game," Marshall said. "Everybody was focused from the beginning of the game." The Heat made just six of their first 26 shots, missing 10 in a row during one stretch to fall behind 32-12, drawing the first wave of boos. Eddie Jones led the Heat with 12 points, but was the team's only player to reach double figures. "We're stumbling our way into each and every game," said Miami center Alonzo Mourning, who was held to nine points. "This is all about leadership by example. You can talk all you want, but you have to do it on the court, and that's not happening right now, and I include myself in that group. "The hole is getting deeper and deeper, and now's the time we need to be playing with a sense of urgency. I don't sense that right now." The Jazz, two games into their five-game Eastern road swing, applied the knockout punch early, leading 20-12 after one quarter and stretching that to 47-23 at halftime. "Everybody was helping everybody," Utah center Greg Ostertag said. "Even when somebody did break down, somebody was there to step up. If I could figure out what makes us click like we did tonight, I would bottle it and sell it."

Game notes
Before the game, the Heat re-signed point guard Mike James and placed Sean Marks on the injured list. James signed with the Heat last summer as a free agent out of the CBA and made it all the way to the final cut just before the start of the regular season. Marks, a backup center/forward, was placed on the injured list with a cervical strain. ... Malone has led the Jazz in scoring 17 times. ... The Heat are trying to give more minutes to Chris Gatling, which likely will means he'll spell Mourning more often at center. ... Utah is 22-8 lifetime against Miami. ... Utah's road trip that continues in Orlando, Boston and New Jersey. ... The NBA record for fewest points in a game is 49 by Chicago against Miami on April 10, 1999.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
